docs.snippet: Alonzo Galloway Decker Jr., who made Black & Decker into a household name by putting power tools on the do-it-yourselfer's work bench, died Monday at his home in Earleville, Md. He was 94.    The idea underlying the company's success came to him d...
docs.lead_paragraph: Alonzo Galloway Decker Jr., who made Black & Decker into a household name by putting power tools on the do-it-yourselfer's work bench, died Monday at his home in Earleville, Md. He was 94. The idea underlying the company's success came to him during World War II when he was vice president for marketing. He found out that workers in war production took their Black & Decker tools home from the job to work with them around the house after hours.
docs.abstract: Alonzo Galloway Decker Jr, who made Black & Decker into household name by putting power tools on the do-it-yourselfer's work bench, dies at age 94 (M)

docs.snippet: The bodies of two German and three Danish  soldiers killed earlier this week in an accidental explosion in the Afghan capital of Kabul arrived today at a military airport in this city in western Germany.    The remains of the first German  soldier...
docs.lead_paragraph: The bodies of two German and three Danish soldiers killed earlier this week in an accidental explosion in the Afghan capital of Kabul arrived today at a military airport in this city in western Germany. The remains of the first German soldiers to die in the American-led war on terrorism were returned home as officials expressed irritation at a leak concerning the nature of a mission undertaken by another group of German soldiers belonging to an elite commando unit.
docs.abstract: Bodies of two German and three Danish soldiers killed earlier this week in Afghan capital of Kabul arrive at military airport in Cologne, Germany (S)

headline.main: Dead Soldiers Are Received By Germany

docs.snippet: Edwin H. May Jr., who served one term in the United States House of Representatives and was a co-founder of what became the Greater Hartford Open golf tournament, died on Wednesday in Fort Pierce, Fla. He was 77 and lived in Wethersfield, Conn., a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Edwin H. May Jr., who served one term in the United States House of Representatives and was a co-founder of what became the Greater Hartford Open golf tournament, died on Wednesday in Fort Pierce, Fla. He was 77 and lived in Wethersfield, Conn., and Stuart, Fla. The cause was a heart attack, his son, Edwin H. May III, said.
docs.abstract: Edwin H May Jr, one-term congressman from Connecticut, dies at age 77 (M)

headline.main: Edwin H. May Jr., 77, Former Congressman

docs.snippet: At the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics, there is an array of technologies devoted to portraying the hidden dimensions of athletic performance in ways never quite seen before. But when all is said and done, success or failure rests, in one sport at ...
docs.lead_paragraph: At the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics, there is an array of technologies devoted to portraying the hidden dimensions of athletic performance in ways never quite seen before. But when all is said and done, success or failure rests, in one sport at least, on the most fleeting of impressions. That sport is figure skating, and the impressions that count are those flashing through the judges' minds. There can be no recall of Monday night's scoring for the pairs medals. The judges gave the gold, after a flawed performance, to the Russian duo of Yelena Berezhnaya and Anton Sikharulidze instead of the Canadian pair Jamie Salé and David Pelletier, who skated perfectly. Any replay will show Sikharulidze faltering on a double axel and Berezhnaya landing stiffly after several aerial maneuvers. Yet when the scores were posted, Russia, China, Ukraine, Poland and France put the Russians first, while the United States, Canada, Germany and Japan gave first to the Canadians.
docs.abstract: Editorial says gold medal in pairs figure should have gone to Jamie Sale and David Pelletier of Canada rather than to Yelena Berezhnaya and Anton Sikharulidze of Russia; says injustice is throwback to judging in cold-war sports competitions (M)

docs.snippet: John Erickson, one of the foremost scholars on the development of the Red Army and its role in World War II, died on Feb. 10 in a hospital in Edinburgh. He was 72.    He had come down with a bad case of the flu and then contracted an infection, fr...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Erickson, one of the foremost scholars on the development of the Red Army and its role in World War II, died on Feb. 10 in a hospital in Edinburgh. He was 72. He had come down with a bad case of the flu and then contracted an infection, from which he died, said a friend, David M. Glantz.
docs.abstract: John Erickson, Briton who was one of foremost scholars on development of Red Army and its role in World War II, dies at age 72; photo (M)

headline.main: John Erickson, 72, Dies; Briton Chronicled the Red Army

docs.snippet: Newcomers and old acquaintances got together at the New York State Theater on Wednesday night when the New York City Ballet presented Jerome Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering.''    Helene Alexopoulos, Eva Natanya and Rachel Rutherford made debuts ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Newcomers and old acquaintances got together at the New York State Theater on Wednesday night when the New York City Ballet presented Jerome Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering.'' Helene Alexopoulos, Eva Natanya and Rachel Rutherford made debuts in this celebration of youth and friendship. Ms. Alexopoulos looked proud but also a bit too smug in her solo as the woman in green. Ms. Natanya was playful as the woman in blue. And Ms. Rutherford was both sweet and faintly enigmatic as the woman in mauve.
docs.abstract: Jack Anderson reviews New York City Ballet performance of Jerome Robbins's Dances at a Gathering at New York State Theater (M)

headline.main: A Vietnam-Era Vision of Love and Hope

docs.snippet: Gulf Arab states urged Iraq today to allow United Nations weapons inspectors back into the country or risk more tension in the Middle East.    The leaders of the states, members of the Gulf Cooperation Council, also called on Iraq at their year-en...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gulf Arab states urged Iraq today to allow United Nations weapons inspectors back into the country or risk more tension in the Middle East. The leaders of the states, members of the Gulf Cooperation Council, also called on Iraq at their year-end summit meeting here today to show good will toward its neighbors and respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Kuwait, which Baghdad invaded in 1990 before being driven out seven months later by a multinational force led by the United States.
docs.abstract: arab states urge iraq to allow arms inspr

headline.main: Arab States Urge Iraq to Allow Arms Inspectors Back in Country

docs.snippet: China, worried about its waning influence in Central Asia, said today that it would sponsor a meeting with foreign ministers of Russia and Central Asian countries next month to discuss Afghanistan's future and the war on terrorism.    The ad hoc m...
docs.lead_paragraph: China, worried about its waning influence in Central Asia, said today that it would sponsor a meeting with foreign ministers of Russia and Central Asian countries next month to discuss Afghanistan's future and the war on terrorism. The ad hoc ministerial meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization -- which also includes Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan -- is set for Jan. 7 in Beijing, the Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Zhang Qiyue, said.
docs.abstract: China, worried about waning influence in Central Asia, calls meeting with foreign ministers of Russia and Central Asian countries to discuss Afghanistan's future and war on terrorism (S)

docs.snippet: A senior American diplomat met this week with North Korea's ambassador to the United Nations in the highest-level bilateral talks since President Bush denounced North Korea as part of an ''axis of evil,'' the State Department said today.    Charle...
docs.lead_paragraph: A senior American diplomat met this week with North Korea's ambassador to the United Nations in the highest-level bilateral talks since President Bush denounced North Korea as part of an ''axis of evil,'' the State Department said today. Charles Pritchard, the Bush administration's special envoy for North Korea, met with the ambassador, Pak Gil Yon, on Wednesday and agreed to continue the discussions at a later date, according to Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman.
docs.abstract: Bush administration envoy Charles Pritchard meets with North Korea's UN Amb Pak Gil Yon in highest-level bilateral talks since Pres Bush denounced North Korea as part of 'axis of evil' (S)

headline.main: U.S. and North Korea Hold High-Level Discussion
